data.title: Option to toggle tab drawing
data.body: Added an option to toggle drawing of tabs within the text editor.

data.title: Add -r flag to adb install for keep app user data
Multipass material support.
data.body:
Okay, this PR retools how materials are handled internally somewhat. Materials now include the concept of having multiple 'passes', which contain all the information originally containined in the root material. This is a concept I've seen in many renderers including Ogre3D and Unity's ShaderLab system (which also both include the concept of a fallback mechanism for unsupported shader features; may be worth considering something similar in the future). What this means is that the renderer can render the same instance multiple times but with different shaders and render parameters. The easiest to describe use-case for something like this is rendering an object with an outline using an inverse hull, without having to do the rather cheap hack of just rendering multiple versions of the same geometry on the editor side of things.

Internally on the renderer side of things, not much has changed besides the fact that things are sorted via passes rather than materials now. More could probably be done to provide greater optimization advantages to a multiple pass material system (for example, it may be worth adding a mechanism of skeletal and morph modifications to be cached between multiple passes using the same material on the same instance), but it shouldn't incur any significant penalities to pre-existing functionality, and should also retain backwards compatibility with pre-existing content.

On the editor side of things, the most notable inclusion is that of the new multi-pass material type which allows you to set the number of passes, and then shaders and params for each pass. FixedMaterials and ShaderMaterials still remain and should work exactly as they did before. The only thing I was not able to keep as backwards compatible was changes to the VisualServer frontend due to needing to add new arguments for creating materials, but I don't imagine many people interacting with the VisualServer directly and it's very trivial to change such code. I also just pushed a PR for a minor fix for the tree gui control, and this is needed due the highly dynamic nature of the multipass material's parameter. On the whole, there are probably a lot more interesting things which can be done with this feature beyond the scope of what I had in mind, but this at least should provide a competent self-explanatory frontend to remove the need for a lot of rather inelegant hacks for certain graphical features.

Again, if there are any questions about this PR, please ask me.

data.title: Fix cursor getting locked on tree control
data.body: If the user is modifying a numerical tree element and the tree gets cleared, the cursor would be stuck as locked invisible. This fixes this by reverting the cursor state when calling the clear method.

data.title: Fixes for Word highlighting
data.body: Fixes for word highlighting as discussed [here](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/pull/4076)

data.title: Update Android build system for NDK 11
data.body:
With the release of a new version of the Android NDK, some things need to change in Godot's build system. The new NDK is deprecating GCC in favor of Clang. Also, GCC 4.8 is not bundled anymore, so we must look for GCC 4.9 instead, even though Clang should become the default.

Just as a note, this will also require an update to the documentation about compiling for Android.

data.title: BoxContainer: Add helper method add_margin(int)
data.body:
I couldn't find a way to make margins work inside BoxContainer. The only possible solution seems to be adding a control with a minimum size:

``` C++
Control *margin = memnew( Control );
margin->set_custom_minimum_size(Size2(0, 10)); // vertical margin of 10
vbc->add_child(margin);
```

However this is too verbose so I added this helper method.

**Just to be sure...** Is there a better way to add a margin to (or to make margins work inside of) _BoxContainer_?

data.title: Godot 2.0 does not run on Nvidia GeForce Go 7300 gfx card with nouveau drivers.
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Freshly installed Debian 8 Testing also OpenSusye Tumbleweed (rolling release).
Core2Duo 64-bit laptop, nvidia gfx card (described in laptop specs as Nvidia GeForce Go 7300) with Nouveau display driver (no proprietary drivers installed).

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Clicking Godot's icon  outputs "Segmentation fault" in terminal and Godot not starting at all. You can see the the windows blink for a split of the second and that's it.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Install Debian 8 Testing (or OpenSuse Tumbleweed)
Download Godot files from the official site.
Unpack the files into one directory.
Click Godot_v2.0.1_stable_x11.64 binary or run it from the console.

data.title: Allow select multiple files in ResourcePreloaderEditor
Highlight all occurrences of selected word

data.title: get_global_mouse_pos() doesn't respects stretch_aspect
data.body:
Windows 7 64 bits, Godot 2.0.1

I tried to add simple look at to my game, but I noticed a strange return value of the get_global_mouse_pos function(), leading to a wrong behaviour.

Test project: http://zylannprods.fr/dl/godot/LookAt.zip
Start the scene, look at seems fine. But resize the window horizontally or vertically so black bands appear. Notice the sprite doesn't looks at the mouse correctly.

It seems the virtual center stays nearby the origin of the window and doesn't "follows" the viewport:
![Screenshots](http://zylannprods.fr/images/screen/godot/LookAt_screens.png)

QA thread: http://godotengine.org/qa/1515/how-to-make-a-moving-character-look-at-the-mouse

data.title: Better Collada Exporter - export only deform bones
data.body:
Hello,

Testing the Better Collada Exporter for Blender, I notice all of the bones in a rig get exported to Godot. A desired way would be to only export those bones that directly influence the mesh (i.e. deform bones). In Blender, bones can be flagged as being 'deform' bones and e.g. the FBX exporter has an option to only export those. It would be nice and very much needed for Better Collada to support this.

A rig is usually made from many bones. There are deform bones which directly deform the mesh, then there are control bones that are used to animate, and also helper bones. Together they make a rig comfortable to use and animate. However, for games, you only need the deform bones, the rest can and should be discarded.

data.title: Exiting godot doesn't stop adb
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Arch Linux 64 bits and steam version of godot

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When I exit godot (steam version, I have not tried with the non steam one) the adb process doesn't close itself so steam says that I am in game and I have to manually kill the process

**Steps to reproduce:**
-Start steam version of godot from steam
-Launch a project
-click the cross to exit godot
-use top command
-see that there is an adb process running
-see that steam says that you're in game
-kill the adb process
-steam no longer says that you're in game

data.title: Explain what is required to make proper HTML5 export
data.body:
Continuation of:
https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/4000#issuecomment-197373433

To work on better **web export**, it is rather critical to see a picture that explains in sufficient technical detail how Godot components work together. Current HTML5 export is slow and "counter-productive", so is there a visualization that explains why?

Even if this is obvious, it will  help to design a better architecture for in Godot 4.0 or whatever. For example, it may be possible to provide architecture that may be able to export only a subset of games (such as various static menus and clickers).

data.title: GDScript desync between editor and file
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Linux Mint 17.3

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Editor doesn't recognize that the code has changed when you undo after a cut. If you cut a line of code and run it, stop, then undo, then run again the editor should recognize the change and update code in the file when pressing run, but instead it doesn't until you make another change.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Write a line of code ex: `print("hello)`
2. Run game ("hello" is have printed)
3. Cut that line of code
4. Run game ("hello" is not have printed)
5. Press Undo to restore that line of code
6. Run game ("hello" should have been printed but wasn't)
7. Add a new line
8. Run game ("hello" is printed)

**Note**
Title of this issue should be changed to something along the lines of "Editor doesn't recognize that the code has changed when you undo after a cut."

data.title: CollisionPolygon2D deleting/undo/redo doesn't make effect until making new polygon/editing other
data.body:
There is something wrong about making changes with 2D CollisionPolygons. When deleting / making some undo / redo it does changes visualy - it disapears / appears ( in scene tree, and the render itself when the debug is on ). There is also a change in the scene file, but there must be something buffered out there, because it still colides / doesn't collide until you make some new collider and you put at least one point into or edit some collider - that belongs to the same PhysicsBody2D object (!). Editing, adding new one for one PhysicsBody2D doesnt fix problem for other objects.

Godot 2.0.1, Windows 7

data.title: percent decode destroys dictionary
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Ubuntu 14.04 64-bit

Happens If someone did not encode the string.

Example: 

```
    var s = "ax"
    print(s)
    var de = s.percent_decode() #error
    print(de)
    var dict = {}
    dict[de]="test"
    print(dict)
```

OUTPUT:

ax
unicode error: invalid utf8
a
(a

How can I catch this error?

https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/e46e43d2aaa6339a1675eb989f41885e745bf5c3/core/ustring.cpp#L3628

data.title: Error at modifying children of an inherited scene
data.body:
Hi. So, this is what I got:

scene_parent.scn:
o Node2D
___o Sprite

I created an inherinted scene base on that one:

scene_child.scn:
o Node2D
___o Sprite

Modifying the node "Node2D" gives me not problem, but when I modify the node "Sprite" and play the scene_child.scn the Debugger throws an error, this is what the console says:

`ERROR: _set_owner_nocheck: Condition ' data.owner ' is true.
   At: scene/main/node.cpp:1059.`

Even though, the scene keeps running. Any thoughts?

EDIT:
It doesn't interfier with the game. I'm just reporting the error that keeps showing. I played Tank of Freedom, I opened the game with the console and it shows a few error two, something with the node.cpp, but the game goes smoothly without any problem. So I'm gessing it's just godot internal stuff.

data.title: LineEdit/TextEdit: Add Shift+Delete shortcut for cut
data.body:
Closes #4060

This PR was only supposed to add this shortcut, but I found some inconsistencies with the copy, cut and paste code in TextEdit, which produced weird results when combining shortcuts and menu actions (e.x.: cutting with _Ctrl+X_ and pasting with _Edit -> Paste_).

Now both the shortcuts and the menu actions use the same code.

Let me know if you prefer this to go into a separate PR.

data.title: UndoRedo mergeable modes improvement
data.body:
Follow-up on #3433.

@reduz wrote:

> there are many cases of mergeable where you want the whole set of undo and redo actions, such as painting data in tilemap. Instead I propse to change the mergeable mode into an enum like
> MERGE_DISABLE,
> MERGE_ALL,
> MERGE_ENDS
> 
> and move some cases to MERGE_ENDS

There might be some other issues with UndoRedo that would be worth looking into, I'd propose to create one issue for each and maybe make a tracker bug for all UndoRedo issues if there are many. Currently the behaviour is far from optimal in many use cases.

data.title: Enable shift+del as "cut" in text editor.
data.body:
It'd be pretty nice if the text editor allowed using the keyboard shortcut shift+del, usually "cut text" in most toolkits, text editors and OSs. Using it in Godot just deletes the text without adding it to clipboard, which can be misleading when you try paste the text later. 
The shortcut shift+ins for paste and control+ins for copy already work, so it'd be nice to have its complementary in place as well

data.title: Sound is not reloaded when it changes on disk
data.body:
Windows 7 64 bits, Godot 2.0.1

When I open a sound in Audacity, modify and overwrite it, Godot doesn't notices the change. I have to restart the editor to listen for the new audio.
I don't know if it's a bug or usability enhancement, it would be useful for sure :)
